results.title: North of Nutcracker
results.creator_credit: Daryl Binning and Film Communications of Australia
results.brief_description: Illustrates the many facets of planning for, and co-ordinating a bushfire controlled program, utilising available local personnel and equipment in Western Australia.

results.title: North of 60 east
results.creator_credit: T.R. Wagstaff, E.L. Burnell, Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: On patrol with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police of the eastern Canadian Arctic, north of the 60th parallel. This film shows the day-to-day routine of constables who police the vast area that includes Baffin and Ellesmere Islands. For those who might choose northern service, the film provides clear impressions of the requirements of this detachment; for the general audience it gives an interesting overall view of the people, life and environment in the eastern Arctic.

results.title: North Kimberley expedition
results.brief_description: An area of some 30,000 square miles in the North Kimberleys, Western Australia has not been settled. The film covers a survey expedition ot the great expanse of uninhabited country between Karunjie-Gibb River and Kalumburn Mission. Expedition leader: John F. Morgan.

results.title: North China factory
results.creator_credit: Tony Ianzelo, Boyce Richardson, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: North China Factory gives the audience a chance to see a factory community in China where over six thousand workers process, spin and weave raw cotton into ninety million yards of high-quality cloth per year. Also seen are the workers’ residential, social, recreational and educational facilities, all of which are located on factory property. Highlights of the film are the retirement and wedding ceremonies, in which factory management plays a major part. The film is an engrossing study of a lifestyle that is very different from that of the Western world.

results.title: North by northwest
results.brief_description: Alfred Hitchcock nominated this literal cliff hanger as the film that most epitomised the elements of his years of making thrillers. Roger Thornhill (Cary Grant) is a smug but successful Madison Avenue advertising executive who is plunged into the world of espionage when he his mistaken for mythical agent George Kaplan who US intelligence has created to flush out spies. Matters are further complicated when he meets Eve Kendall (Eva Saint-Marie) who further jeopardises his life while being romantically involved with him. Kidnapped by spies, Thornhill escapes but is then accused of killing a UN diplomat. He is pursued by both spies and the police and desperately flees across country, buzzed by a crop duster plane in one of the films most memorable scenes. His meeting with arch spy James Mason on the Mount Rushmore monument provides the heart-stopping climax as the pair fight it out on the giant sculptures of former US presidents.

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

results.title: North and south of the Niger
results.creator_credit: John Page and Taurus Film Productions
results.brief_description: Gives a picture of the various parts of Nigeria, and their peoples, and of Nigeria’s social problems. In the north, near the Sahara desert, the people are Mohammedans. In the central plateau live pagan peoples who herd cattle or practice a hoe agriculture. Near the coast, in the eastern provinces, live another pagan people, who get their living from the rain forests. In the western provinces, European influence is greatest. A Nigerian doctor living here explains some of Nigeria’s problems, especially in regard to health and food supply.

results.title: North-west horizon
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The ports, mineral resources and industries of north-west Australia. Broome, with an overseas port, pearling, whaling, manganese; Port Hedland, Wittenem Gorge and asbestos mines; Derby, the cattle port; oil exploration, rice growing; iron ore at Yampi Sound; bean-growing at Caernavon; Wyndham and the beef industry; the role of aircraft in this area.

results.title: North-West Coastal Highway
results.brief_description: Shows how the Main Roads Department of Western Australia is completing a modern road from Carnarvon to Port Hedland as part of the National Highway number 1 encircling the continent. Explains some aspects of its effect on the development and prosperity of the area.

results.title: Normandy
results.brief_description: Normandy has an exciting past of conquest and liberation and is now a popular holiday destination. This tape takes in sights such as; the port of Dieppe, Mont St Michel, a cruise down the River Seine to the city of Rouen, Monet’s gardens at Giverny, the streets of Bayeaux, the countryside surrounding the Suisse Normande, the harbour at Honfleur, and on a more historical note visit the D-Day landing beaches and Caen, where William the Conqueror lies entombed.

results.title: Normandie-Niemen
results.creator_credit: Damir Viatich Berejnykh, Jean Dreville and Simon Mariakhine
results.brief_description:
In 1942, 16 French pilots decide to join forces with the Red Army and participate in the Battle of Stalingrad.

Credits: Producer, Simon Mariakhine ; directors, Jean Dreville, Damir Viatich Berejnykh ; writers, Charles Spaak, Elsa Triolet, Constantin Simonov ; photography, Jacques Natteau ; music, Rodeon Stchedrine.
Cast: Marc Cassot, Giani Esposito, Pierre Trabaud, Gerald Buhr, Georges Riviere.
